description:
A shrine is suggested to have been somewhere under the modern Goldsmith's Hall. Masonry foundations are reported to have been recorded there, and a probably 2nd CE altar with an image identified as Diana was found there.

It's also notable that the site is only roughly 300 metres north-west of the two Gresham Street temples.
bibliography: Shepherd, J., Hall, J., (2008), Places of worship in Roman London and beyond, in Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain
Perring, D., Brigham, T., (2000), Londinium and its Hinterland: The Roman Period, The archaeology of Greater London, pg. 135
Toynbee, J., (1962), Art in Roman Britain
